description: Imitative. First attested in 1846 in the intransitive sense of "bleat". Compare English bleat, Old English blǣtan (“to bleat”).

verbs.description: blat (third-person singular simple present blats, present participle blatting, simple past and past participle blatted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To cry, as a calf or sheep; bleat.

examples: A moment later the engine roared into life. Exhaust blatted through the straight-pipes; people stopped on the street to look.

entries.meaning: To produce an overrich or overblown sound on a brass instrument such as a trumpet, trombone, or tuba.
(transitive) To utter loudly or foolishly; blurt.

description: Borrowed from Russian блат (blat), from Polish blat (“cover, umbrella”) or Yiddish בלאַט‎ (blat, “leaf, list”). Doublet of blade.

entries.meaning: The Soviet system of connections and social relationships; one's social or business network (in Russian or Soviet society).
examples: To open a new business in Russia you need blat.
